reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 17, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A MUST READ
reviews.reviewText: It's 1930s Mississippi. Magic is permitted only in certain circumstances, and by certain people. Unsanctioned broom racing is banned. But for those who need the money, or the thrills...it's there to be found. Billie Mae, Loretta, Cheng-Kwan, Mattie, Emma, and Luella will all work together as a family - biological and chosen - to find freedom, agency, safety, and love in a world that not only denies them freedom but actively persecutes them.This is a book that stays with you long after you read it. Though it’s a graphic novel, it’s not a quick read - every page has such deep illustrations and rhetoric that it is best read slowly, with contemplation. The characters are incredibly strong, even when afraid, and it is magical to watch them love and support each other. While so many at that period in history did not get a happy ending - and still don’t today - the book ends in a wonderfully satisfying way.Whether you’ve never read a graphic novel, or have and love them, this is a book worth reading that anyone can find joy and meaning in, as well as learn from.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars do yourself a favor and read this
reviews.reviewText: I really enjoyed the mix of fantasy and historical references in this book. I also loved the representation the characters brought.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars New favorite graphic novel
reviews.reviewText: Wow! That's all I can say. Brooms is probably my new favorite graphic novel. I read it twice in 24 hours and have since revisited it often. The story and art are woven together perfectly and it's so nice to see queer people of color get happy endings in historical fiction. I'd highly recommend it.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 18, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Both in storytelling and visuals this book just knocks it out of the park. Highly recommended.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 23, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars READ IT NOW, you won’t regret it!
reviews.reviewText: oh MAN this was incredible. the found family!! men who cook!! the absolutely stunning art (including the little bonus drawings at the end 🥺 & how sign language was drawn)!! luella and billie mae and the rest of the group will stay in my heart forever. <3

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Queer and witchy!
reviews.reviewText: I love a graphic novel that can tackle a lot while adding magical realism and great art.Brooms is about 1930s Mississippi where only certain people can use magic so people that aren’t allowed have started illegal broom racing games.Queer. Witchy. With a lot of disability representation.Thanks to NetGalley and Levine Querido for an eARC.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars An excellent book
reviews.reviewText: NetGalley ARC Educator 550974The art and story will absolutely draw you in. Magic in the 1930s and African Americans with magic, this is a wonderful book for fans of Harry Potter that wanted to see more diversity in the films and books. I wish this would have been a series.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 4, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A must read!
reviews.reviewText: I absolutely loved this! The historical setting in Depression era Mississippi combined with the fantasy world building of magic and broom racing is so well done. The main characters are all from marginalized communities and are faced with period typical racism and racist laws. In this story, Black people aren't allowed to learn or practice magic, and Indigenous children are often taken to residential schools if their families can't pay to exempt them. In this time of scarcity and danger, this band of young women and girls compete in dangerous broom races to win prize money that will get them closer to securing safer futures for them all. The story is compelling, and I love the glimpses of backstory that reveal the early friendships between Bille Mae, Luella, Loretta, and Cheng Kwan. I especially liked how the girls learn that Cheng Kwan is trans and immediately accept her and welcome her into their friend group. The art is so good! I've been a fan of Teo DuVall's work for years, and I thoroughly enjoyed gazing upon their artwork in Brooms. The character designs are really cool; I like that there's a wide variety of body types, ages, skin tones, etc.. There's also disability rep with multiple characters, all of which is portrayed with care. I was really impressed by how this story skillfully shows these characters in all their complexities, and tells an exciting tale of magic, risk, and new beginnings. A must read!
